snippet: Beneath an orderly display, the cardinals at the papal conclave are split into competing lineups and power blocs that will determine who among them emerges as pope.
abstract: Cardinals who will enter the papal conclave to determine the next pope are mostly split between Romans, cardinals who work in Vatican, and reformers, cardinals who want next pope to tackle Vatican's corruption, inefficiency and secrecy; Romans' top preference is Cardinal Odilo Pedro Scherer, Brazilian archbishop of Sao Paulo, while reformers are pushing for Cardinal Angelo Scola, Italian archbishop of Milan.

byline.original: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
byline.contributor: Ian Austen contributed reporting from Ottawa, and Dan Bilefsky from Budapest.

lead_paragraph: Beneath an orderly display, the cardinals at the papal conclave are split into competing lineups and power blocs that will determine who among them emerges as pope.

headline.seo: Among Cardinals, Deep Divisions Over Next Pope
headline.main: Before Smoke Rises at Vatican, It’s Romans vs. the Reformers
headline.print_headline: Before Smoke Rises at Vatican, It’s Romans vs. the Reformers
